联合国种族主义委员会周五对自 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击以来，包括高级官员在内的以色列人针对巴勒斯坦人的“种族主义仇恨言论和非人化行为急剧增加”表示担忧。

以色列驻日内瓦外交使团批评这一声明，称其“辜负了10月7日大屠杀的所有受害者以及全世界反犹太主义袭击的受害者”。

以色列称，哈马斯枪手在以色列南部发动袭击，造成约 1,400 人死亡，220 多人被扣为人质，导致以色列对加沙地带进行了数周的袭击。哈马斯统治的加沙卫生部表示，7000多名巴勒斯坦人在空袭中丧生。

以色列还加强了针对约旦河西岸伊斯兰组织的行动。

自冲突爆发以来，关于美国和英国等地反犹太主义和仇视伊斯兰教事件的报道越来越多。

总部位于日内瓦的委员会表示，对以色列高级官员、政界人士和公众人物最近发表的言论“高度关注”，并呼吁以色列谴责仇恨言论并调查和惩罚此类行为。

它特别提到了以色列国防部长约阿夫·加兰特10月9日的言论，他在讲话中将巴勒斯坦人称为“人类动物”，并称这种语言“可能煽动种族灭绝行动”。加兰特的言论已经引起巴勒斯坦人和其他人的谴责。

该委员会还重申了过去对巴勒斯坦当局打击仇恨言论和煽动暴力的建议。

以色列驻日内瓦联合国外交使团表示，该委员会的声明忽视了反犹太主义的高涨，包括对犹太人的袭击以及抗议者呼吁谋杀他们的行为。 “这一切都被委员会冷嘲热讽地抛弃了，”它说。

联合国委员会发表上述评论之前，以色列批评了该全球机构秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯，指责古特雷斯为哈马斯对以色列的袭击辩护。古特雷斯驳斥了以色列的指控，称这些指控是对他言论的歪曲。

该联合国委员会由 18 名独立专家组成，负责监督以色列和巴勒斯坦当局均批准的 1965 年反种族主义条约的遵守情况。

俄罗斯国防部周五确认任命维克多·阿夫扎洛夫上将为俄罗斯航空航天部队司令，接替8月份被免职的谢尔盖·苏罗维金将军。

俄罗斯国营通讯社俄新社和塔斯社上周援引消息人士的话说，报道了他的任命。

俄罗斯航空航天部队由其武装部队的空中和航天军种组成。

55 岁的阿夫扎洛夫在苏罗维金被解职后一直担任航空航天部队代理司令。基辅表示，阿夫扎洛夫在俄罗斯 2022 年 2 月 24 日针对乌克兰发起的“特别军事行动”的策划和实施中发挥了直接作用。

苏罗维金因在俄罗斯干预叙利亚内战期间使用地毯式轰炸战术而被称为“世界末日将军”，去年曾短暂领导俄罗斯在乌克兰的战役，但于一月份被降职。

他在俄罗斯军事机构的强硬批评者中很受欢迎，其中包括瓦格纳老板叶夫根尼·普里戈任（Yevgeny Prigozhin），后者于 6 月 24 日领导了一场失败的兵变。普里戈任于 8 月的一次飞机失事中丧生。

曾受到普里戈任公开赞扬的苏罗维金在兵变后从公众视野中消失。 《纽约时报》报道称，美国情报部门相信他事先就知道这次叛乱，这是对弗拉基米尔·普京总统执政 24 年来权威的最大挑战。

9月，苏罗维金显然重返公务，作为俄罗斯国防部代表团的一员，访问了俄罗斯武器的主要买家阿尔及利亚。

周五，以色列安全部队限制巴勒斯坦年轻人进入耶路撒冷的阿克萨清真寺进行祈祷，并在老城及其他地区部署了兵力，以平息加沙冲突引发的骚乱。

巴勒斯坦官方通讯社WAFA称，在被占领的约旦河西岸，以色列军队在袭击中杀死了四名巴勒斯坦人。武装派别确认其中两名死者是其成员。

路透社记者称，当巴勒斯坦人周五聚集在一起祈祷时，大批以色列警察在阿克萨清真寺周围守卫，阿克萨清真寺是常年爆发的热点地区，也是经常发生冲突的地点。他们一度发射催泪瓦斯。

自10月7日哈马斯袭击以色列南部以及随后以色列轰炸和围困哈马斯统治的加沙以来，巴勒斯坦人连续第三周被限制在清真寺祈祷。

他们被迫在老城外祈祷，聚集在路边，以色列安全部队在一旁观看。

最终大约5000名老年信徒被允许进入。负责该清真寺的当局耶路撒冷伊斯兰捐赠部门表示，通常会有约 5 万人参加。

清真寺坐落在一座被犹太人称为圣殿山、被穆斯林称为高贵圣所的山上。

在约旦河西岸，以色列军方表示，在逮捕行动中，其部队在杰宁市遭到袭击并开火还击，造成两人死亡。

伊斯兰圣战武装组织证实其中一名武装分子属于该组织，哈马斯称其一名武装分子在杰宁战斗中丧生。

WAFA表示，另有两名巴勒斯坦人被杀，一名在杰宁，一名在盖尔基亚镇。他们的死亡使自哈马斯与以色列冲突爆发以来西岸被杀的巴勒斯坦人人数达到110人。

军方表示，在盖勒奇亚，军队在关闭一家商店时遭到枪击，该商店的店主被指控煽动暴力。一份军方声明称，他们还击，击中至少一人。

约旦河西岸的希伯伦也发生了抗议活动。

在邻国约旦首都，数千人走上街头谴责以色列并表达对巴勒斯坦人的支持。许多人挥舞着绿、红、白、黑相间的巴勒斯坦国旗。

与会者马哈茂德·阿卡兰说：“我们与巴勒斯坦人和加沙人站在一起。我们还强调，我们将支持抵抗运动直到最后。”

另一位抗议者哈桑·苏丹说：“我们的兄弟在加沙被杀。这是我们至少能做的——让世界知道我们的立场。”

英国前首相鲍里斯·约翰逊周五表示，他将加入英国新闻电视台，为他担任《每日邮报》专栏作家的工作增添了另一个媒体角色。

约翰逊在 X 节目中表示：“我将向这个非凡的新电视频道表达我对从俄罗斯到中国、乌克兰战争、我们如何应对所有这些挑战以及我们面前的巨大机遇等一切问题的坦率看法。” 。

英国新闻称，约翰逊将从 2024 年初开始担任主持人、节目制作人和评论员，并将在报道预计明年举行的英国下一次全国选举以及美国选举中发挥关键作用。

该电视频道于 2021 年推出，融合了新闻、观点和分析，与其他英国广播公司相比，更类似于福克斯新闻等美国网络。英国广播监管机构多次裁定该电视台违反公正性规则。

约翰逊是英国脱欧运动背后的主要政治领导人，他于 2019 年成为首相，并在当年晚些时候的选举中赢得了多数席位。但在一系列丑闻导致他失去许多保守党议员的支持后，他于 2022 年辞职。

约翰逊在从政前曾担任记者，六月开始为《每日邮报》撰写专栏。

周五发布的一项调查显示，超过二百个西班牙人中就有一个可能遭受过天主教神父的性虐待，并指出全国范围内的受害者人数比之前的类似调查要多得多。

西班牙人权监察员的调查是周五向议会提交的报告的一部分，调查询问了 8,000 多人。该文件批评教会没有更充分地配合调查并寻求“尽量减少这种现象”。

监察员安吉尔·加比隆多 (Angel Gabilondo) 表示，0.6% 的调查样本表示，他们曾受到牧师的虐待，如果包括教堂机构教师等非专业人士的虐待，这一数字上升至 1.1% 左右。

他在提交报告后的新闻发布会上表示：“通过引用 0.6%，你可以看到它对总体滥用行为的影响程度。”西班牙人口约为4800万。

西班牙教会发言人拒绝对该报道发表评论。

教会在美国、爱尔兰和法国等多个国家面临性虐待丑闻，西班牙 6 月发布的一项内部调查发现，自 20 世纪 40 年代以来，西班牙有 728 名被指控的施虐者和 927 名受害者。

此前《国家报》2021 年的一篇报道指出了1,200 多起涉嫌案件。

监察员的报告发现，近 65% 的受虐待者是男性，报告还呼吁设立国家基金来赔偿受害者。

代理总理佩德罗·桑切斯在评论调查结果时告诉记者：“多年来，许多人因无法谴责、解释、让人类戏剧可见而遭受痛苦。”

来自马德里的 62 岁导游费尔南多·加西亚·萨尔莫内斯 (Fernando Garcia-Salmones) 表示，自己 14 岁时被学校的一名牧师强奸，他告诉路透社，他现在可以翻过这一页了。

1995年，他将此案告上法庭，但因诉讼时效而被驳回。

他希望这份报告能够“结束整个国家对教会罪恶的有罪不罚、沉默和不道德行为”。

40 岁的卡德是附近美国陆军预备役基地的一名中士，执法官员称他今年夏天被暂时送往精神卫生机构。

王毅为期三天的访问是中美之间一系列外交接触中的最新一次，此行主要是为预计将于 11 月在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织领导人会议期间举行的习拜登峰会做准备。弗朗西斯科.中国尚未宣布习近平是否出席。

周四，王告诉布林肯，两国存在分歧，需要“深入”和“全面”对话，以减少误解并稳定关系。 “我们不仅应该恢复对话，而且对话应该深入、全面，”王通过翻译说道。

拜登政府与北京的首要任务是防止两个最大经济体之间的激烈竞争以及在贸易、台湾、人权和南海等一系列问题上的分歧演变成冲突。

As Israel prepares to open a ground offensive in Gaza after weeks of relentless bombardments, some residents of the Palestinian enclave say they are ready to fight the Middle East's most powerful military with their bare hands.

"Even if all our men die, we will fight," said Um Moatasem Al-Alami, whose house was hit by an Israeli air strike.

"We are not deterred by all they do, despite the wounds. We will get them out of our land even with our nails," she said.

Israel says it is preparing a ground invasion, but it has been urged by the United States and Arab countries to delay an operation that would multiply the number of civilian casualties in the densely populated coastal strip and might ignite a wider conflict.

There are also fears about what a ground invasion would mean for the more than 200 hostages reported to be held there by Gaza's ruling Islamist Hamas movement and other militant groups.

Mohammad Abu Daqqa and his family are not taking any chances especially since Israel mounted a series of small incursions. He left his home in the town of Abassan Al-Kabira east of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip because of the intensity of the Israeli bombing.

They are staying in a tent inside a UN shelter. Like other Palestinians he does not want a repeat of the Nakba, the Arabic word for catastrophe that refers to the 1948 war of Israel's creation that led to their mass dispossession.

In the war surrounding Israel's founding, some 700,000 Palestinians, half the Arab population of what was British-ruled Palestine, fled or were driven from their homes, and have been denied return. Many ended up in Jordan, Lebanon and Syria as well as in Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

"This is our land and they are fighting us inside it, for how long we will be in this bloodshed and this hardship?" said

Abu Daqqa. "Anyone who will come up here we will kill him, whoever comes."

The Hamas-controlled Gaza health ministry said on Thursday that 7,326 Palestinians had been killed in the retaliatory air strikes, including 3,038 children.

Israel and the United States say they doubt the Gaza health ministry's figures but they have not supplied estimates of their own.

以色列称，哈马斯在 10 月 7 日的暴乱中杀害了约 1,400 人，其中包括儿童。

Palestinian militants clashed with Israeli troops in at least two areas inside the Gaza Strip, the latest of several small-scale incursions, Hamas-affiliated media reported. The Israeli military did not immediately confirm the sortie.

加沙中部的居民表示，他们听到了听起来像是交火的声音，以及边境沿线的猛烈炮击和空袭，以色列飞机投掷照明弹和炸弹。

Aside from the fear of losing their land, Gaza residents are facing a growing humanitarian crisis with shortages of food, water and medicine.

Some aid was allowed in from the Egyptian border but Palestinians and aid agencies say it is not nearly enough.

Israel has already tightened its blockade of Gaza, fully banning food and fuel imports and cutting the electricity supply. Israeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant has warned that the price Gaza would pay "will change reality for generations".

At an intensive care unit of Gaza's Nasser hospital, doctors cannot keep up with the casualties.

"We had to open new intensive-care unit, but these units are not fully equipped, they lack artificial respiratory systems and machines to monitor the patients," said Dr. Hamouda Shaath.

"Because of the war and the current conditions we can't receive abdominal or heart cases. The fate of those cases, patients who suffer chronic illnesses or other diseases is unknown," he said.

The UN food agency said on Friday severe fuel shortages may force it to stop supplying emergency food aid to thousands of displaced families in Gaza.

"Only two of our contracted bakeries have fuel to produce bread at the moment and tomorrow there might be none," World Food Programme (WFP) representative Samer Abdeljaber said.

"This would be a terrible blow to the thousands of families living in shelters who have been relying on the daily bread deliveries," he said in a statement.

President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Friday Russian forces have lost at least a brigade worth of troops trying to advance on Ukraine's eastern town of Avdiivka.

Russia renewed a push to encircle the embattled town in mid-October, trying to overwhelm Ukrainian positions with constant barrages of artillery and waves of troops and fighting vehicles, according to local and military authorities in Ukraine.

"The invaders made several attempts to surround Avdiivka, but each time our soldiers stopped them and threw them back, causing painful losses. In these cases, the enemy lost at least a brigade," Zelenskiy told British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in a phone call, the president's office said in a statement.

Reuters could not independently verify the assertion and there was no immediate comment from Russia.

Brigades vary in size and can number between 1,500 and 8,000 troops. Battlefield losses are a state secret in Russia and Ukraine, though they are believed to run into the many tens of thousands on both sides since Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

Russian military bloggers have reported territorial gains by Moscow's troops in the area, while Ukraine has described the situation as extremely difficult and said Moscow was throwing a huge number of forces into the assault.

Russia's offensive at Adviivka has become the battlefield focus nearly five months after Kyiv launched a counteroffensive in the occupied south and east. Kyiv has made slower progress than it wanted to due to vast Russian trenches and minefields, but it continues to report small gains in the strategic south.

The Institute for the Study of War, an American non-profit research group, said on Thursday that Russia had taken heavy losses in equipment near Avdiivka that would "likely undermine Russian offensive capabilities over the long term".

In a battlefield update on Friday, the Ukrainian General Staff said the military "steadfastly holds the defence and causes significant losses" to Russian troops, adding they were not giving up in their attempts to encircle the town.

Avdiivka, about 25 km (16 miles) from Russian-occupied Donetsk, is surrounded by Russian-held territory to the north, east and south, leaving only its west for Kyiv's troops to resupply and evacuate people.

The town, which is home to a vast coking plant, has been under attack since 2014 when conflict first broke out between Ukraine and Russian-backed forces. Vitaliy Barabash, head of Avdiivka's military administration, said the renewed attacks to capture the town were the largest since 2014.

美国总统乔·拜登对巴勒斯坦官员提供的加沙伤亡数字表示怀疑，但国际人道主义机构认为这些数字大致准确且历史可靠。

哈马斯控制的加沙卫生部做出回应，发布了一份 212 页的文件，其中包含约 7,000 名巴勒斯坦人的姓名和身份号码，据称这些人在以色列轰炸该飞地时丧生。

国际组织，甚至一些在加沙活动的组织，以及包括路透社在内的全球媒体无法核实这些数字，但记者看到了大量尸体。

联合国和其他国际机构表示，最终伤亡数字与加沙卫生部在袭击发生后立即报告的数字之间可能存在微小差异，但他们普遍相信这些数字。

联合国人道主义事务协调办公室（OCHA）在给路透社的一份声明中表示：“我们继续将他们的数据纳入我们的报告中，并且来源明确。”

“目前几乎不可能提供任何联合国日常核查。”

总部位于纽约的人权观察组织也表示，伤亡数字总体上是可靠的，并且在核实过去对加沙的袭击时没有发现重大差异。

“值得注意的是，考虑到人口稠密地区的轰炸强度，自 10 月 7 日以来公布的数字总体上与人们预期的杀戮规模一致或符合逻辑。”人权观察说。

数据大致一致

世界卫生组织官员周五表示，该机构收到的估计显示，加沙废墟下仍有约 1,000 具身份不明的尸体，尚未计入死亡人数，这突显了计算死亡人数的困难。官方并未具体说明消息来源。

虽然哈马斯控制着加沙并对来自飞地的信息实行严格控制，但卫生部的正式责任仍然由西岸的巴勒斯坦权力机构（PA）承担。

巴勒斯坦权力机构由哈马斯在巴勒斯坦的主要竞争对手法塔赫主导，负责支付加沙医院的工资和设备。

拉马拉的一位发言人表示，该组织根据从医院、救护车和紧急服务部门收到的数字，与红新月会协调报告了伤亡总数。

他说，受害者最初是根据年龄、性别和受伤类型进行识别的，随后会确认完整的身份。他说，这些数字最初是在加沙报告的，并在检查后在拉马拉进行更新，但差异通常很小。

一年前，当中国共产党公布其205名中央委员会成员名单时，有一个明显的遗漏：总理李克强。

李克强于周五因心脏病去世，享年 68 岁，他被排除在外似乎证实了许多人长期以来的假设——他的经济改革方案已被正式放弃，取而代之的是国家主席习近平的国家主导的经济方针。 。

在努力重振疲软的消费需求并抵御日本式的经济停滞之际，改革再次成为中国政策制定者和分析人士关注的焦点。

但习近平领导下的中国并没有推动许多经济学家所倡导的变革，例如重新城镇化和为私营企业提供更多空间，而是将更多权力交到了国家手中。

“毫不夸张地说，一个可以稳步推进改革的时代已经结束，”一位不愿透露姓名的政府政策顾问表示。

李克强在担任中国第二高领导人和私营企业倡导者十年后于三月退休，但在习近平使自己成为中国几十年来最强大的领导人并加强对经济和社会的控制后，他的权力受到限制。

这位拥有精英北京大学经济学博士学位的英语国家总理致力于改善企业家的条件、吸引外国投资者、减少繁文缛节和提高穷人的收入。

但北京在 2013 年推出的雄心勃勃的市场化改革很快就遇到了麻烦，其中包括 2015 年因货币改革失败而引发的股市崩盘。在习近平的领导下，世界第二大经济体逐渐回归旧政策，这些政策加剧了中国的债务负担和工业产能过剩。

芝加哥大学政治学教授杨大利表示，“在习近平主席的领导下，李克强的决策和执行范围变得更加从属，习近平毫不掩饰地主导着政治和政策制定，使李克强沦为次要角色。”

盟国

中国的经济奇迹始于1978年，当时邓小平发起了历史性改革，允许更多的私营企业发展并向外国投资开放经济。

李并不是唯一一位最终被排除在外的支持改革的领导人。前经济沙皇刘鹤、前银监会郭树清、前央行行长易纲均已离开政府。

相反，习近平在政府中塞满了他的盟友，其中大多数是国际或金融经验有限的官员。

北京正在推出新一轮刺激措施以提振经济复苏，但经济学家警告称，中国可能会陷入长期通货紧缩和增长停滞，从而无法提高14亿人民的生活水平。

一些政府顾问一直在大力推动改革，重点是刺激城市化和家庭消费能力，减少对投资的依赖，并在国有企业和私营企业之间创造公平的竞争环境。

预计将于 11 月召开的共产党全会历来侧重于改革，但可能会让那些等待重大变革的人失望。

“我预计改革不会取得任何突破，”政府政策顾问表示。

US President Joe Biden and his team have markedly shifted their tone on the Israel-Hamas crisis in recent days, moving from unfettered support of Israel to emphasizing the need to protect Palestinian civilians in Gaza ahead of a looming Israeli ground invasion .

Biden has not changed his fundamental belief that Israel has the right and responsibility to defend itself in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack from Hamas militants that killed 1,400 people in southern Israel, aides say.

But a rapidly rising Palestinian death toll, the difficulty of freeing hostages held by Hamas and an increasingly vocal outcry from Arab nations, European allies and some Americans at home , have pushed Biden's team to support a humanitarian pause to Israel's attacks and focus on getting aid to Palestinians, say multiple sources inside the administration and out.

A White House official said the shift in tone was based on "the facts on the ground" in Gaza with a humanitarian crisis worsening and the Biden team's "conversations with countries around the world."

There has been a tug of war behind the scenes among Biden and his advisers about the US message, said one former official who is in touch with current officials.

"We've seen sort of an evolution from sort of full-throated, unconditional hugging of Israel to a little bit more nuance," the former official said.

The administration had not expected Palestinian casualties to mount as fast as they have – now more than 7,000 dead in Gaza, local officials say – or for the humanitarian situation to deteriorate so rapidly, a US official said on condition of anonymity.

"I think the framing has clearly changed, unsurprisingly, in response to changing circumstances and what appears to be an even greater looming catastrophe should the Israelis move into Gaza with a major campaign," said Aaron David Miller, a Middle East expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

Biden, 80, has evolved in the face of a challenging 2024 reelection bid, threats by some would-be supporters to withhold their votes over his lack of backing for Palestinians, and a warning from former President Barack Obama that Israel's actions could backfire.

Israeli officials and their US supporters have privately voiced concern to Reuters that as more time passes since the Oct. 7 atrocities committed by Hamas, the more the world's focus will be on death and destruction from the Israeli assault in Gaza.

Biden's aides are urging their Israeli counterparts to take more time to carefully think through their exit strategy before a full-scale ground invasion, one US source said.

US officials have cautioned that crafting fine points of such a strategy "on the fly," as was often the case for the US in the early stages of the Iraq war, would be a mistake, the source added.

US military advisers sent to the region are urging Israeli counterparts to be cautious because any invading force will face difficult fighting terrain and a warren of tunnels and booby-trapped buildings that could increase casualties among Israeli soldiers and Gaza civilians, a separate source familiar with the conversations said.

In rare comments on an active foreign policy crisis Obama, Biden's Democratic predecessor and former boss, warned this week that Israel cutting off food and water to Gaza could "harden Palestinian attitudes for generations."

The White House did not respond when asked if the administration coordinated with Biden's Democratic predecessor.

ARAB LEADERS PRESSURE

When Hamas militants burst out of Gaza and attacked southern Israel on Oct. 7, Biden offered full-throated support for Israel, saying he relayed to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that "Israel has the right to defend itself and its people. Full stop."

He did not mention the Palestinian people.

Addressing reporters before departing for the Middle East on Oct. 11, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the top objective of his trip was a robust show of solidarity with Israel, including providing all the military equipment that it needs to defend itself.

"The United States has Israel's back," Blinken said. He didn't mention humanitarian aid at all.

During Blinken's six-day trip, the death toll in Gaza soared from Israeli air strikes and concerns grew about food and water. Every Arab leader Blinken met in the region pressed him to urgently find a solution to the rapidly deteriorating situation in Gaza.

Blinken relayed the concerns of Arab leaders, while others spoke to the US president directly.

The intense protests against Israel that followed last week's blast at a Palestinian hospital , which the United States and Israel both blamed on Palestinian militants, also alarmed US officials.

The protests were reminders of the risks of escalation during any ground assault, US officials said, because they show how Israel's adversaries could seek to wield disinformation to spark unrest.

HUMANITARIAN PAUSE

The most rapid shift in US policy has happened this week, to support a cessation in Israel's attacks on Gaza to allow aid in and people to escape.

Asked on Oct. 23 about international demands for a humanitarian pause, White House security spokesman John Kirby said the United States wants to make sure "Israel has the tools it needs to defend itself and to go after Hamas and that humanitarian assistance keeps flowing."

A day later, Kirby and Blinken advocated for one publicly. The shift followed a plea from UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres for civilians to be protected and increasingly desperate appeals from UN organizations to allow in aid.

The US revised its own UN resolution from a focus on Israel's right to defend itself to include calls for all measures, specifically to include humanitarian pauses, to allow unhindered humanitarian access of aid.

Remarks made by Biden on Wednesday are in contrast with those on Oct. 7, and show a new direction. "Israel has to do everything in its power, as difficult as it is, to protect innocent civilians," Biden told a press conference.

He offered a rare criticism as well of Israel's "extremist settlers" on the West Bank, accusing them of pouring gasoline on a fire, and called for a “concentrated effort,” once the crisis is over, to work toward an accord under which Israel and a new Palestinian state would exist side-by-side in peace.

But Biden also expressed skepticism toward Palestinian estimates of the death toll and a continued staunch support of Israel. He told the press conference that he had "no confidence" in the numbers the Palestinians were using about Gaza's dead.
